title: 109_hr5143
content: The "H-Prize Act of 2006" establishes prize authority under the Department of Energy, defining key terms such as administering entity and Secretary. The Secretary will award cash prizes to advance hydrogen energy technologies through competitive programs, encouraging broad participation from individuals, universities, and businesses. Prize competitions will be advertised widely, including in the Federal Register. The Secretary will award cash prizes for hydrogen energy technology advancements through competitive programs. A private entity will administer the competitions, including advertising, fundraising, and developing winner selection criteria. The Secretary will award cash prizes for hydrogen energy technology advancements through competitive programs. Prizes will be selected based on goals provided by the Secretary, with judges chosen according to specific criteria. Funding sources include Federal appropriated funds and funds from the administering entity. Unauthorized use of participants' intellectual property will be prevented. The Secretary will award cash prizes for hydrogen energy technology advancements through competitive programs. Prizes will be announced only when funds are secured, and the authority to announce prize competitions under this Act will end on September 30, 2017. The Secretary will award cash prizes for hydrogen energy technology advancements through competitive programs. Prize categories will be announced only when funds are secured, and the authority to announce prize competitions under this Act will end on September 30, 2017. The Secretary will establish prizes for advancements in hydrogen technology components and systems, prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles, and transformational changes in hydrogen production and distribution technologies. The Secretary will establish biennial awards for significant advances in hydrogen technology components, prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles, and changes in hydrogen production and distribution technologies. Prizes may not exceed $1,000,000 each, and adjustments may be made if less than $4,000,000 is available for the competition. The Secretary will hold a biennial prize competition for prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles and transformational technologies. Prizes may not exceed $4,000,000 each, and if no participants meet the criteria, no prize will be awarded. The prize offered shall be a minimum of $10,000,000, paid in a lump sum to the winner, with additional matching funds provided for each dollar of private funding raised by the winner for hydrogen technology. The matching funds will be provided for 3 years or until the full prize amount is paid out. The winner can choose to have the matching funds paid to another entity continuing the technology development. The Secretary will announce the rules for receiving the matching funds in the required notice. The prize will only be awarded when a registered participant meets the established criteria. The criteria for the prize award under this paragraph include consulting with various entities such as the Department's Hydrogen Technical and Fuel Cell Advisory Committee, other Federal agencies, and private organizations. The administering entity aims to raise $40,000,000 for the matching award. The Secretary will assemble a panel of judges from outside the Department, including the private sector, to select winners based on established criteria. Judges must not have personal or financial interests in participants or have relationships with them. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY. To win a prize under this Act, individuals or entities must comply with requirements in the Federal Register notice, be incorporated in the U.S. with a primary place of business, and not be a Federal entity or employee. SEC. 6. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. SEC. 6. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. The Federal Government will not claim intellectual property rights from participants in prize competitions authorized by this Act. It does not prevent the government from negotiating a license for the developed intellectual property. The Secretary may require registered participants to waive claims for any injury, death, or property damage during competition. Liability insurance is mandatory for registered participants. Registered participants must obtain liability insurance or show financial responsibility for claims by third parties for death, injury, or property damage during competition. The Federal Government must be named as an additional insured under the insurance policy, and participants must agree to indemnify the government against third-party claims related to competition activities. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2016 includes $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(1), $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(2), and $10,000,000 for the award in section 4(a)(3). Additionally, $2,000,000 is authorized for administrative costs each year. Funds for prize awards under this Act are available until expended and can be transferred. The funds authorized in this Act can be used until expended, transferred, reprogrammed, or expended for other purposes after 10 fiscal years. No provision in this Act allows the use of funds in violation of the Anti-Deficiency Act. SEC. 9. NONSUBSTITUTION. The programs created under this Act are not a substitute for Federal research and development programs.
